text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 10th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
When he returns in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and walks up the stairs for the remaining three floors to reach his apartment.
However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.

Why does he only take the elevator to the 7th floor on non-rainy days? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I need to figure out why this man takes the elevator only to the 7th floor on non-rainy days.
Let me start by breaking down the problem.
First, the man lives on the 10th floor.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor (which is the 1st floor) to go to work.
In the evening, when he returns, he takes the elevator up to the 7th floor and then walks up the stairs for three more floors to reach his apartment.
But on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way back to the 10th floor.

So, why doesn't he take the elevator all the way home on non-rainy days?

Hmm, maybe it has something to do with the time or effort he's saving.
Let me think about how the elevator works.
If the elevator goes from the ground floor to the 10th floor, it has to go up 9 floors.
In the evening, when it's not raining, he only goes up to the 7th floor, which is 6 floors up.
So, on non-rainy days, he's not taking the elevator all the way, which might save him time or effort.
Wait, but if the elevator is faster, why wouldn't he take it all the way? Maybe it's about the building's elevator system.
Perhaps the elevator is designed to stop at certain floors efficiently.
If he takes it all the way to the 10th floor every evening, the elevator might have to make more stops or wait longer for him, which could be inconvenient or time-consuming for others.
Alternatively, maybe the man is trying to save on the elevator fare.
If he takes the elevator only to the 7th floor, he pays less for each trip, so over time, that adds up.
But the problem doesn't mention anything about paying for the elevator, so maybe that's not it.
Another angle: perhaps the building has a policy about elevator usage.
Maybe after a certain time in the evening, the elevator only goes up to a certain floor, like the 7th, and he has to walk up from there.
But the problem mentions that on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way, which implies that on non-rainy days, he can't, so there must be a building rule.
Wait, maybe it's about the elevator's speed or how it's programmed.
If the elevator is faster when going down, but slower when going up, or if it stops at certain floors, he might prefer to get off earlier to avoid waiting or delays.
Or perhaps it's about the effort of walking the stairs.
If he takes the elevator to the 7th floor, he only has to walk 3 floors, which is easier than walking up from the ground floor.
But on rainy days, he might not mind taking the elevator all the way because it's quicker and he doesn't want to get wet walking up the stairs.
Wait, that makes sense.
On non-rainy days, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and walks up because it's quicker than waiting for the elevator to go all the way up, which might be slower or require more stops.
On rainy days, he doesn't want to walk up the stairs, so he takes the elevator all the way to save time and avoid getting wet.

So, the main reason is that on non-rainy days, he prefers to walk up the stairs from the 7th floor because it's faster and more convenient than waiting for the elevator to go all the way up, which might be slower or have more stops.
On rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to avoid walking in the rain.

</think>

The man takes the elevator only to the 7th floor on non-rainy days because walking up from the 7th floor is faster and more convenient than waiting for the elevator to go all the way up, which might be slower or have more stops.
On rainy days, he prefers to take the elevator all the way to avoid getting wet while walking up the stairs.
